ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

FISHING IN INDIAN AND INDONESIAN WATERS


    1. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in view of the frequent arrests of Singapore fishermen by the Indian and Indonesian authorities for fishing in Indian or Indonesian territorial waters, if his Ministry will approach the Governments of India and Indonesia with a view to seeking an arrangement whereby Singapore fishermen may be permitted to fish in Indian and Indonesian territorial waters on payment by them of a tax or royalty.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, first, I think it is necessary for the Member to appreciate that national territorial waters are very jealously guarded by the nations that claim these waters. In fact, there will be a number of international conferences held under the auspices of the United Nations and developing countries of the world to resolve law of the sea matters arising out of territorial water claims. Therefore, the proposal by the Member is not likely to be acceptable to the nations concerned, since the basic problems underlying fishing rights have yet to be resolved in the context of the law of the sea.

    With regard to the Member's suggestion that my Ministry might negotiate with the governments concerned to allow Singapore fishermen to enter their territorial waters to fish, I wish to inform the Member that this has already been tried. The Ministry of National Development went even further and proposed payment of royalties to a number of countries where our fishermen are allegedly intruding into their territorial waters to fish. The response to such approaches, I am sorry to say, has not been favourable because of defence and security requirements. There are also problems relating to piracy and the control of nationals of these countries fishing in their own territorial waters.

Column: 430



    Since the Government has failed to obtain an agreement for licensing of Singapore fishermen in such territorial waters, it might be perhaps better that the applications by individuals to do so would be given more favourable consideration, and I propose that the Member could take up this proposal with the fishermen concerned.

SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Examination of books and transactions)


    2. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Communications if he will appoint a competent officer of his Ministry to thoroughly examine the books and transactions of the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited before he authorises bus fare increases; if he had caused such an examination to be made before authorising the last bus fare increases on 10th February, 1974; and if he was satisfied without any doubts that the operating losses of the company as reported were unavoidable, true and correct.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as explained in press statements issued by my Ministry on 3rd and 20th February, and in replies given by me to recent Questions in this House, the bus fare revision effective from 10th February was allowed after two reports were submitted in August and November last year by professional management consultants commissioned by Singapore Bus Service Ltd. These were closely studied and examined by officials of the Ministry of Communications.

    The reports of the management consultants were based on the certified and audited accounts of the three constituent bus companies, which comprise SBS. Checking and examination of books of these three companies were done by the auditors of the three bus companies concerned. These certified and audited accounts for the year ended 31st March, 1973, were later submitted to my Ministry separately. However, one of the three bus companies' accounts

Column: 431

had the following serious qualification by its auditors, which goes as follows:

    `We report that we did not obtain all the information and explanations we required because of:-

    (a) an absence of adequate internal controls;

    (b) an absence of external documentary evidence to support certain payments; and

    (c) a failure to properly maintain accounting and other records.'

    In assessing the reports submitted by the management consultants, my officers had access only to these certified and audited accounts for the year ended 3 March, 1973, as well as to other data obtained from the three bus companies and other sources. In addition, my officers also worked independently of the reports of the management consultants on projected revenue and expenditure of Singapore Bus Service Ltd, based on their own source material. This was used as an independent counter-check against the results of the management consultants.

    All these studies took several months and involved very detailed work. Actual examination of the books of the three former bus companies was not undertaken by my officers for two reasons - firstly, there is no competent accounting staff in the Ministry of Communications and, secondly, it would only have duplicated the work of the auditors of these companies. But the bus companies had, naturally, to convince me that a fare revision was necessary and also as to when the revision would have to be effected, as well as how much it should he, before approval for the revision was given. On the basis of:

    (a) the audited accounts of ABC, ABS and UBC for year ended 31st March, 1973;

    (b) the submission of the case for a bus fare revision, on behalf of SBS by its professional management consultants, SGV-Goh (Pte) Ltd, in August and November, 1973; and

Column: 432



    (c) the counter-checking of figures and projections made by my officials in the Ministry of Communications,

I was satisfied that the projected operating losses of SBS, on the old fare structure, would have brought it to a state of insolvency by the middle of this year. Inaction would have brought about an even worse situation than the Singapore Traction Company because when STC, with a paid-up capital of over $14 million, folded up bus operations in December, 1971, it had then an accumulated loss of $9 million. The bus fare revision, which was authorised on 10th February, 1974, and for which I assume full responsibility, was necessary for SBS to be viable. It is all the more necessary if it is expected to improve on its services over the next three years, as required by my Ministry.

    As stated in an earlier answer to the Member for Kallang on 14th March, should the need arise, I will not hesitate to exercise my powers under section 9A of the Bus Services Licensing Authority (Amendment) Act, 1973 (No. 27 of 1973) to appoint an Inspector to inspect the affairs of SBS. And, should it he in the public interest to do so, I would also cause the report of the Inspector to be published.

    Encik Abdul Aziz Karim (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very satisfied with the answer, and I would like to thank the Minister for Communications.

HOUSING BOARD FLAT TENANTS AND OWNERS
(Ownership of private property)


    4. Mr Ho See Beng asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether a person, who is already a tenant or owner of a Housing and Development Board flat, may own property.

    Mr E. W. Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, a tenant of a Housing Board flat who buys private property will have his Tenancy Agreement terminated and be evicted by the Housing and Development Board.

    An owner of a Housing Board flat is not at the moment prohibited from purchasing private property. This is because when the Home Ownership Scheme was first started, very few people desired to buy Housing Board flats and the Board wanted to encourage our citizens to do so.

    However, the situation has now completely changed. With the introduction of the Central Provident Fund Financing Scheme, more and more contributors to the Fund have taken advantage of the Scheme and registered to purchase HDB flats. As a consequence, there are now more than 80,000 applicants registered to purchase flats. In addition, of course, there are others who want to rent fiats, and most of them will have to wait for some time before being allotted a flat. It is, therefore, considered unfair to allow any Housing Board flat owner to retain his flat if he purchases private property. By "private property,"

Column: 435

of course, I mean private landed property.

    The Board is, therefore, now considering introducing legislation to provide that any HDB flat owner who purchases private landed property must resell his flat to the Board, subject to perhaps certain exceptions, e.g, those owners who inherit property jointly with other beneficiaries.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the Minister's reply, the HDB tenant would have no alternative but to give up his tenancy. However, under extenuating circumstances, would the Minister exercise a little bit of flexibility? There is the case of a shophouse tenant who was affected by urban renewal. The Housing and Development Board offered him only a residential flat and so he could not do his business. So he had to buy a shop-house in order to run his business, upon which his family's livelihood depends.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, every case will, of course, be treated on its merits. But in the case cited by the Member for Bras Basah, perhaps I should ask him a question. Why did his constituent not rent a shophouse, instead of buying it?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, I think you are more than aware that today it is not so easy to rent a flat. That is why I think this poor fellow was forced to purchase the shophouse, not because he did not want to rent one.

    Mr Barker: With your permission, Sir, can I ask another question? Is it not easier and cheaper to rent, surely, than to buy especially if, as the Member said, he is a "poor fellow"?

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, in the long-term I think it is cheaper to buy than to rent.

INSTITUTE OF MEDICAL SPECIALITIES
(Particulars)


    6. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Health and Home Affairs, in respect of the Institute of Medical Specialities project, (a) how much money stands to the credit of the fund related to the project; (b) how much of the total donated was to be used for purposes specified by donor, and to what extent have such specified schemes been implemented; (c) how much interest has accrued out of the moneys collected for the Institute of Medical Specialities, and to what use has the interest been put; and (d) how far have plans for the implementation of the Institute of Medical Specialities project been carried through, and what is the intention of his Ministry with regard to the future of this project.

    The Minister for Health and Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in answer to part (a) of the Question, as at 28th February 1974, a sum of $3,548,359 stood to the credit of the Medical Progress Fund.

    (b) about 48 per cent or $1,321,757 of the total sum of $2,736,308 donated was to be used for specified purposes. A one-storey building for the Radiotherapy Department was completed in the Outram Road General Hospital in 1968. The cost of the project was $908,168. This comprised $620,690 for construction works and $305,478 for equipment and furniture. The equipment for the establishment of this speciality included the installation of a cobalt bomb unit. Half of the project cost, or

Column: 437

$454,084, was met from the Medical Progress Fund and the other half by the Government in accordance with the Government's pledge of a dollar-for-dollar contribution.

    (c) interest accrued, from August 1965 to February 1974, on the moneys collected for the Medical Progress Fund amounted to $1,410,188. The interest has been put in fixed deposits for the purpose of generating further interest.

    (d) as originally conceived in 1965, the Institute of Medical Specialities was to have been built as a completely separate building within the compound of the Outram Road General Hospital.

    However, this concept has been superseded by events relating to the development of medical specialisation in Singapore. In December, 1969, I appointed a Committee to investigate the extent of development of medical specialities and to recommend a programme of development or creation of a number of selected specialities in order of priority, to achieve eminence as a centre of medical treatment, training and research.

    The report of the Committee of Medical Specialisation was received in October, 1970. The Government in accepting the report also decided that the recommended specialities of Neuro-Surgery, Cardio-thoracic Surgery, Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Paediatric Surgery and Nephrology, should be developed within an integrated plan of expansion of the Medical Services in Singapore.

    This expansion plan included the building of new hospitals. The most significant of this hospital building programme is the re-development of the Outram Road General Hospital.

    The Government has now decided that all the major specialities which have been recommended for development will ultimately be housed in the new hospital to be built at Outram Road. This new hospital, which will be known as the Singapore General Hospital, will be Singapore's premier hospital and specialist centre.

Column: 438



    In July, 1973, the International Development and Construction Corporation (INDECO) was commissioned to build the new hospital at Outram Road on behalf of Government. The planning, preliminary site works and architectural designing of the new hospital are proceeding according to time-table. It is expected to be put to tender for the construction of the first two phases of the hospital before the end of the year.

    Since the original donations for specified schemes towards the development of the Institute of Medical Specialities have now been overtaken by these new developments as well as become inadequate as a result of rising costs, the Government has now decided to ask the donors to agree to their donations being used towards the development of this new premier hospital and specialist centre at Outram Road.

    When the design plans for the new buildings of the hospital are sufficiently advanced for visualisation of elevations, with models as well as more precise estimates of costs have been worked out, the donors of the Medical Progress Fund will be invited to a public meeting when the plans of this new development will be put to them.

    Mr Ho See Beng: Sir, when this new hospital is ready, I would like to know by how much will the Minister increase the medical fees, which at one time were free.

    Mr Chua Sian Chin: Sir, firstly, that supplementary does not arise out of the Question. Secondly, the first two phases of this new hospital will be completed sometime at the end of 1977. So I do not think I am in a position to answer the Member for Bras Basah on an event that will occur in 1977.

SINGAPORE BUS SERVICE LIMITED
(Tax exemptions)


    7. Encik Abdul Aziz Karim asked the Minister for Finance if the Singapore Bus Service (Private) Limited is given exemption or concession in respect of payment of any duty or tax; and what

Column: 439

is the rationale of continuing this policy when it has failed to serve the public interest.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore l3us Service Ltd was given a waiver of the transfer fees on the buses which were re-registered following the amalgamation of the three Chinese bus companies. This waiver was also previously given to the three Chinese bus companies when they took over the buses of the former bus companies, including the Singapore Traction Company. The waiver was given because the amalgamation of the bus companies was being encouraged by Government for the purpose of reorganising and improving the public transport system.

    Because of the urgent need to increase the number of buses on the roads, exemption from import duty was given to the Singapore Bus Service Ltd recently for the purchase of 19 assembled units of bus chassis. However, no waiver or reduction of additional registration fee has been given to any of the bus companies.

    Since the various bus companies have already been amalgamated into the Singapore Bus Service Ltd. there should he no further occasion for re-registration of buses and hence for the payment o transfer fees. Nor should there be any need for future imports of fully assembled buses by this company. Completely knocked down or CKD packs do not attract import duty.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, Sir, repair and maintenance bills are given tax allowance. As repair bills can be $1 and upwards, like any other professional bill, is it possible that excessive repair and maintenance bills cause leakages in the SBS finances?

    Mr Speaker: Will the Member for Kallang please repeat his supplementary question?

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Sir, I was saying that repair and maintenance bills are given tax allowance. My question is this.

Column: 440

Is it possible for excessive repair and maintenance bills to cause leakages in the SBS finances, when it comes to taxation? Badly maintained vehicles require frequent repairs, and if SBS send their buses to disreputable firms for repairs, they are prone to over-charging. Would that cause less tax to be collected?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not aware that excessive hills were paid. If the Member would please give me particulars of this information, I would get my tax people to look into whether there is an excessive deduction from income and tax for maintenance bills. I assume that they would themselves prefer to keep their profits as high as possible and keep the maintenance bills as low as possible.

    Encik Abdul Aziz: Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister for Finance not think that it is the duty of the Income Tax Department to look into these matters whether or not there is information?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, we do not go on a fishing expedition unless we have some basis on which the expedition can be successfully conducted. But, as I say, if the Member would give me any particulars that he knows of, I will look into it.

JOINT INDUSTRIAL TRAINING SCHEMES
(Particulars)


    8. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Finance what sort of joint training schemes were conducted through joint industrial training centres in 1973; what further activities are being planned; how responsibility for those schemes is distributed between the Government and the private sector; if there is any intention to modify the basis of co-operation; and in what ways his Ministry supports other forms of industrial training.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1973, two Government-industry joint industrial training centres were in operation, one in co-operation with the

Column: 441

Rollei Company of Germany and the other with Tata Industries of India. The two training centres have a capacity for training 200 skilled workers each year in the following key skills required in manufacturing:

    (a) Precision machining

    (b) Tool and die making

    (c) Precision mechanics

    (d) Precision optics.

After two years of intensive full-time training at the centres, workers are required to undergo an additional two years of approved in-plant training in industrial establishments selected by the Government.

    The two joint training schemes have proved to be effective. The Government is now exploring the possibility of establishing similar joint training centres with other industrial companies including those in the shipbuilding and repair industries and the machine tool and machinery industries to meet the expected growth of demand for highly skilled workers by companies in these industries.

    The Joint Industrial Training Centres established so far are being administered by the Economic Development Board acting as the Government's agency to supervise and direct their training programmes. Day-to-day operations of these centres are delegated to a management committee comprising three members from Government and two members from the participating private sector company. Government's responsibility is in providing the capital for the establishment of these centres, supply of local instructors and selection of trainees, in addition to its participation in the management committees to assist in the running of the centres. The private companies contribute the industrial training know-how and the supply of foreign instructors from industries and top technical schools abroad. They also provide in-plant training in their operations in Singapore after in-centre training has been completed.

    There is no immediate necessity to modify the concept of the joint Government-industry training schemes although

Column: 442

the basis of co-operation in each scheme may be varied from time to time on a case-by-case basis.

    The Government also supports the following industrial training schemes:

    (a) The Overseas Training Scheme under which selected Singaporeans are sent abroad to train in the industrial training facilities of established companies in Germany, Switzerland, Sweden and Japan.

    (b) The Industrial Training Subsidy Scheme under which companies with demonstrated capability to undertake in-plant training may be assisted with grants ranging from $3,000 to $9,000 per trainee for a wide range of modern industrial skills. The value of the grant to be given is determined by the type and period of training.

    (c) Industrial Development Scholarship Scheme under which skilled workers may be given scholarships for training locally or abroad to become foremen and supervisors.

    Mr Ng Yeow Chong (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, I merely wish to ask the Minister some questions concerning the provision of $310,000 for new post offices to be established during the new financial year. My questions are: first, is there provision for a new post office at the Old Kallang Airport Estate in my constituency? have made representation to me for a new post office to be set up in my constituency. I am, therefore, taking this opportunity to raise this matter here, and I earnestly hope for a favourable reply from the Minister concerned.

    The following are the places where the post offices will be located.
